captions.text: Crowd: Good morning John, it's Friday!

Hank: Good morning John, today is my first
day off, in like four weeks. The universe

kept conspiring to prevent me from getting
a full night's sleep, and yesterday, I realized

that if it did it one more time, I would destroy
it. The entire universe, I would set it to

flame, and watch it burn. So, I slept. Lucky
for you.

I'm on tour with a rock and roll band right
now, which is really weird. I've been to a

lot of shows in my life, and I will be honest,
never in my life have I not felt anxious before

a show, whether I'm there as a performer,
or just as someone watching the show. The

institution of the show seems to have a lot
of cultural knowledge associated with it and

it also kind of seems like just sort of the
thing like very cool people do. I am not a

very cool person! So I always felt like there's
just a lot of stuff I don't know, and I'm
not sure if I'm doing the right things ever.

It almost seems like part of the coolness
of it is hiding all those do's and don't's

from "normal people" so that you can know
when they're not cool, and that is a thing
I hate.

So on my shows, I've been asking the audience
what is some of the institutional knowledge

of concerts that you think should be shared
with the world, and I've been collecting that

information and now I'm going to share it
with you!
Crowd member: Wear deodorant!
Crowd: *laughs*

Hank: Number one. Bring earplugs! Because
sometimes it is dangerously loud, sometimes
it's not, but you never know!

Number two. You can go by yourself. It's nice
to bring people along with you but you can
also have an amazing time alone.

Three. Make sure you have enough charge on
your cellphone to get you through the night.

Four. You never know how hot it's going to
be, so hydrate and bring layers.

Five. Buy merch on the way in because when
you're leaving, it will a mess and the line
will be a million miles long.

Six. Dance, clap, singing along, every audience
is different and what happens out there affects
what goes on on the stage.

Seven. If you want to be at the front, get
there early. Do not push your way to the front

because you are moving past the people who
got there early so that they could be at the
front. And that's rude.

Eight. As far as I can tell, there's no schedule.
I don't even know when I'm going on as a performer;

it's up to the venue. Generally, doors will
open about an hour before the show actually

starts, and the main act will be on for at
least two hours after the doors open.

Some venues like to leave like thirty minutes
between every single act so that people have

time to buy more drinks (which is how they
make a lot of their money), but none of this

has anything to do with performers. I would
assume that you're not going to be going home

until at least three hours after the doors
open, and maybe more than four.
Nine. Wear comfortable shoes.
Ten. If you ask, you'll probably get an encore.

Eleven. Interact with strangers. Chances are
you're into some of the same things since

you're obviously into the same music. People
are usually pretty nice, chances are they're

as uncomfortable as you are. Like I am right
now.

Thirteen. Moshpits are surprisingly safe;
stage diving is surprisingly dangerous. You

don't want anybody to jump on your head. If
you don't want to be in a moshpit, just leave

the moshpit area. If you do, make sure your
shoes are on tight and your glasses ...they're

all loose items necessary precautions taken,
etcetera.

Twelve. If you feel unsafe or uncomfortable
let the people around you know or let the
venue staff know and they will help you.

And finally, number thirteen. This was shouted
out at my Portland show, and I couldn't hear

the person who shouted it so I asked the people
around that person to shout it at me simultaneously,

and the thing that got shouted at me by dozens
of people was " DON'T WORRY ABOUT LOOKING

COOL!" and it was a glorious moment.
I wish I could start every day with a group

of people shouting that at me. It would be
nice for all of us I think. It would be wonderful

if we could all get this through out thick
skulls, but of course we can't and so we have

to continue repeating it to each other. But
don't worry about looking cool; do you, because

you are fantastic.
I had the whole audience shout it at me again,

and then I had them shout it at each other,
because I think that's the most important

advice when it comes to going to concerts.
It's not about looking cool; it's about being

excited about something together with other
people who are also excited about it.

It has been really, really, really amazingly
fantastic to a part of that for people.

So thanks to everone who've been coming out
to the shows; we've been having a really great
time.
John, I'll see you on Tuesday.

comments.author: anditsjen

comments.text:
As a regular concert goer let me offer some advice too:
1. Don't wear too much clothes on general floor. Trust me on this. You're 
going to be jumping around and grinding against strangers and it's very hot 
(not in a sexy way) and you do not want to have a jacket on. 
2. Don't be afraid to mosh! As he said in he video, mosh pits are 
surprisingly safe! I've seen an entire mosh pit stop because one person 
fell over before, . And even if it doesn't completely stop someone will 
help you up. And afterwards you'll be thankful you did it.
3. Glasses, no. Wear contacts if possible.
4. Pee before the show starts. For the love of god, pee before the show 
starts. 
5. Get as much rest as possible before the concert. Sleepy concerts are the 
worst. 
6. (And as the person with the worst immune system in existence this is 
important to me) If you're sick but still want to go to the show try to 
take antibiotics and eat healthy before the show. I had a terrible double 
eat infection before what I was sure would be the best concert I ever went 
to so I loaded up on pain meds and ear drops before have. It was a smaller 
venue and I'm a minor so they didn't check my bags, but all the large 
venues do. They should let you keep the stuff if you tell them you're sick. 
Just in case though take whatever antibiotics holy need before the show and 
chug herbal teas (see #4) or whatever. 
Good luck, and have fun!﻿

comments.author: Sara McKee

comments.text:
Thanks for the great advice! Some of those things, I already do. I have 3 
bands I'm obsessed with at one level or another and 2 of them, I've seen 
probably about 30 times each - Barenaked Ladies, while not a huge 
commercial success outside of Canada, they have a core group of deadhead 
type fans who follow them everywhere, even on yearly fan cruises - and I 
also love a "bar band" out of Grand Rapids MI, who has traveled all over 
the Midwest for close to 20 years, Domestic Problems. (The 3rd is a fairly 
new obsession who hasn't been to metro Detroit since the obsession started) 
I've stopped going to BNL shows because they are not the same without 
Steven Page :( but I still see Domestic Problems usually a couple times a 
year, at least. With all these concerts under my belt, im still a nervous 
wreck until im there, standing in MY spot. I want to be standing there when 
the doors open, since most of their shows do not have seating, and I must 
be standing down front for their shows! Its folk/pop rock so, NO moshpits 
to worry about. Thank goodness! But water, comfortable shoes and shorts and 
sleeveless shirts are a MUST for me! Otherwise, its WAY too hot. There is a 
lot of dancing and crowd participation that can wear you out, especially 
when you're around 45 years old! ;) 
Over the years, I've met all the band members and most of their wives and 
they are the nicest guys. In Detroit and Grand Rapids, they look for me, my 
husband and my daughter down front and we're always there!! #GoodTimes
Thanks for letting me tell my story, Hank! Keep having a blast on tour and 
maybe someday you'll make it to Metro Detroit!!﻿
comments.author: Christine Crawford

comments.text:
I will argue that the "don't move ahead of people" rule must be broken at 
hard-rock concerts...

I have mixed feelings about moving past people in the crowd. Normally this 
sort of behavior is absolutely inconsiderate. For example, last minute 
merging in traffic sometimes justifies vigilante justice, perhaps even 
stern looks of disapproval.

However, exceptions must be made for rowdy concerts.

Regular rockers know that there's a gradient of rowdiness, which is 
inversely related to personal space. The closer you are to the front, the 
rougher it gets. Personally I like to go wild, mosh, jump around, scream, 
etc. Leaving with injuries is par for the course. Your position in the 
crowd is based on how physical you are willing to be.

Operating this way creates an unpleasant environment for those in the crowd 
who aren't prepared to rough-house. Still, those of us who came to roar and 
go crazy NEED that outlet.

It's unfair to expect the animals in the crowd to remain calm so everyone 
can watch the show in relative peace, and positioned in the order they've 
arrived. If you're not happy with that dynamic, then perhaps general 
admission hard-rock shows just aren't your thing. Also, there are often 
balconies for the less crazy fans.

Additionally, I second that people are extremely considerate of others' 
well-being at even the roughest concerts. Despite what it may look like, no 
one wants to hurt people, or make them feel unsafe. Except maybe that one 
guy... but we all hate that guy.

Never feel weird about asking someone for help if you're feeling 
uncomfortable or unsafe! You'll find the very roughians responsible for 
making you feel that way will happily take a break to help you muscle your 
way to solid ground... then muscle their way back to the pit.﻿

Not just stage diving.  Also crowd surfing.  Dangerous for you.  Dangerous 
for the people under you.  Disruptive to the people under you.  Disruptive 
to the staff and the medical personnel that have to scrape your cracked 
skull off of the floor of the venue.  Don't do it unless you desperately 
need to get out of a dangerous situation.  Bar-none the most idiotic 
selfish behavior one can participate in at a show.  Stop it.﻿

comments.author: natashaxcohen

comments.text:
yooo i go to shows a lot ((mainly kinda pop punk/pop rock alt rock that 
kinda stuff) n here's stuff that could help in those crowds
1) mosh pits, circle pits, wall of death etc are all actually really scary 
at kinda heavier gigs and honestly try steer clear unless you're into that 
stuff. they usually happen in the middle of the crowd so stay at the sides 
if you're new
2) there is a lot of shoving so dont be that asshole that goes "quit 
shoving!" bc chances are you will get shoved even more
3) if you are at the barrier and you pass out or feel ill you will 
definitely get pulled out the crowd and either taken to a more calm part of 
the crowd or the medical room, depends how bad it is
4) make a meeting point in case you get separated from your friends bc it's 
shit scary when you lose them
5) if someone falls, p i c k t h e m u p. cant stress that enough﻿

comments.author: Captain von Kerman

comments.text:
As a crowd management employee, I can't stress #12 enough, especially if 
you're at the front of the GA/floor area, near the crush gates/barricades. 
At the venues where I work, we will specifically pull you over those 
barricades if you are feeling unsafe, unwell, or just plain uncomfortable. 
Just get someone's attention and tell them you need help out, their job is 
to make sure you enjoy the show safely. However, if you use this as a 
method to get closer/on to the stage, we will kick you out.﻿

The first and only show I ever left without having to be dragged out of the 
show was one where the man behind me was continuously unenthusiastic about 
where he was and what he was doing. Please, if you don't like where you are 
or what you're doing, do not blame it on the other audience members. 
(Unless those audience members are being total douches. You should point 
that out.) Because of his negativity, I didn't want to be there either. And 
that's just not fair to a 13-year-old girl.﻿

COOL" at you every morning as you wake up﻿
comments.author: Allison Willner

comments.text: This made me smile :)﻿
